title: #13 Measure your Calibre
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sqrt{\cos x} - \sqrt[3]{\cos x}}{\sin^2x} = \frac{A}{B}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The limit above holds true for coprime integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is negative and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is positive. Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A+B"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"     "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Bonus","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": Evaluate this limit without applying "},{"type":"text","text":"L'Hôpital's rule","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Other problems: Check your Calibre"}]}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Using the property of limits"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"blockquote","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
  "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \lim_{x \to a} \left[ f(x) \cdot g(x) \right] = \lim_{x \to a} f(x) \cdot \lim_{x \to a} g(x)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"
"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can simplify "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0} \dfrac{ {(\cos x)}^{1/2} - {(\cos x)}^{1/3} }{ 1 - \cos^2 x } &= \lim_{x \to 0} \dfrac{ {(\cos x)}^{1/2} - {(\cos x)}^{1/3} }{ (1+\cos x) (1-\cos x) } \\
&= \left( \lim_{x \to 0} \dfrac{1}{1+\cos x} \right) \cdot \left( \lim_{x \to 0} \dfrac{ {(\cos x)}^{1/2} - {(\cos x)}^{1/3} }{ 1 - \cos x } \right) \\
&= \dfrac 12 \cdot \lim_{x \to 0} \dfrac{ {(\cos x)}^{1/2} - {(\cos x)}^{1/3} }{ 1 - \cos x } \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I think that should be 2x, But Didnt it affected the answer? I guess it was a Typo while he was coding.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 13th13^{th}13th roots of unity.
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"w_1, w_2, w_3, \\ldots , w_{13}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are distinct "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"13^{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"text","text":"roots of unity","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\displaystyle \\prod_{k=1}^{13} (2-w_k)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"ab=72"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=\frac{72}{b}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b=\frac{72}{b}+b=17"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This means "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b^{2}-17b+72=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". By the quadratic equation, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=\frac{17 \pm \sqrt{17^{2}-4(1)(72)}}{2}=\frac{17}{2} \pm \frac{1}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". So "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=8, 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b=9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore, as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8^{2}+9^{2}=9^{2}+8^{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", no matter what values we choose for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" we choose, the answer will be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8^{2}+9^{2}=145"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 140 Followers Problem
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Large\lfloor \sqrt{x} \rfloor + \lfloor \sqrt{y} \rfloor + \lfloor \sqrt{z} \rfloor = 140"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the number of non-negative integral solutions to the equation above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"  "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor k \rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents the greatest integer less than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
You can use calculators to calculate the final sum."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of non-negative integer solutions to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \sqrt{x} \rfloor + \lfloor \sqrt{y} \rfloor + \lfloor \sqrt{z} \rfloor  = 140"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equivalent to finding the coefficient of the term "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t^{140}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the expansion,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(1+t^{\lfloor \sqrt{1} \rfloor} + t^{\lfloor \sqrt{2} \rfloor}  +\ldots )(1+t^{\lfloor \sqrt{1} \rfloor} + t^{\lfloor \sqrt{2} \rfloor} + \ldots )(1+t^{\lfloor \sqrt{1} \rfloor} + t^{\lfloor \sqrt{2} \rfloor} + \ldots )"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(1+t + t+ t+ t^{2} +t^{2} + t^{2} + t^{2} + t^{2} + \ldots)^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(1+3t + 5t^{2} +7t^{3} + \ldots )^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=\left( \dfrac{1+t}{(1-t)^{2}} \right) ^3 \text{(Sum of terms in infinite A.G.P)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(1+t)^{3} (1-t)^{-6}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(1+3t+3t^{2} + t^{3})(1+ \binom{6}{1} t + \binom{7}{2} t^{2} + \ldots +  \binom{5+r}{r} + \ldots )"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, the coefficient of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t^{140}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the above expansion is "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large{\binom{145}{140} + 3 \binom{144}{139} + 3 \binom{143}{138} + \binom{142}{137}}=\boxed{3782205855}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That is not how I would have approached this question, thanks for sharing this!

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Instead of searching for non-negative integral solutions, I had tried positive integral solutions. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Good Solution, BTW.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I really did it using tons of paper. Very amazing and magic solutions. I really love it. I use the approach of using sums instead and using a computer to solve it. By then, I have the generalisation. I'm so thunderstruck!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Beautiful Solution! I really love this method. I hadn't seen this solution earlier.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"My solution is more pedestrian than Surya's."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We start with the observation that there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2p+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor{\sqrt{x}}\rfloor=p"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", namely, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p^2\leq{x}\leq{p^2+2p}=(p+1)^2-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of integer pairs "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x,y)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor{\sqrt{x}}\rfloor+\lfloor{\sqrt{y}}\rfloor=q"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{p=0}^{q}(2p+1)(2q-2p+1)=\frac{1}{3}(q+1)(2q^2+4q+3)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Finally, the number of integer triples "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(x,y,z)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor{\sqrt{x}}\rfloor+\lfloor{\sqrt{y}}\rfloor+\lfloor{\sqrt{z}}\rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=140"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum_{q=0}^{140}\frac{1}{3}(q+1)(2q^2+4q+3)(281-2q)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=\boxed{3782205855}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We have that in order for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor \sqrt { x }  \right\rfloor =n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  the following must be satisfied: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\le \sqrt { x } <n+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Squaring both sides we have that: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ n }^{ 2 }\le x<{ n }^{ 2 }+2n+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" There are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2n+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" values that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can take on to statisfy this condition.
We can now take a sum to find the total combinations for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum _{ X=0 }^{ 140 }{ \sum _{ Y=0 }^{ 140-X }{ (2X+1)(2Y+1)(2(140-X-Y)+1) }  } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Here "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor \sqrt { x }  \right\rfloor"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{ X }^{ 2 }\le x<{ X }^{ 2 }+2X+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and so does "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".
Evaluating the sum we have that the number of combinations of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum _{ X=0 }^{ 140 }{ \sum _{ Y=0 }^{ 140-X }{ (2X+1)(2Y+1)(2(140-X-Y)+1) }  }=3782205855 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 140 Followers Problem - 2
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Large \lfloor \log (x) \rfloor  + \lfloor \log (y) \rfloor  + \lfloor \log (z) \rfloor = 140 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If the number of positive integral solutions to above equation can be expressed in the form of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^{b}\times c^{d} \times e^{f} \times g^{h} \times i^{j}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"e"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"g"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are distinct positive primes and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"h"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are positive integers. Then find the value of"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" a+b+c+d +e+f+g+h+i+j "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Details and Assumptions","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor  k \rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" represents the greatest integer less than or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\log k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the logarithm of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to the base 10."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Try its sister problem 140 Followers Problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is my original problem."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This problem is from the set 140 Followers Problems."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of solutions to this equation is equivalent to finding the coefficient of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t^{140}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the expansion,"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(t^{\lfloor \log (1)\rfloor} + t^{\lfloor \log (2)\rfloor} + t^{\lfloor \log (3)\rfloor} + \ldots)^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=(9+90t + 900t^{2} + 9000t^{3}+ \ldots)^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=729 (1+10t + (10t)^2 + (10t)^3 + \ldots )^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=729 \left( \dfrac{1}{1-10t} \right)^{3} \text{(Infinite G.P.)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=729 (1-10t)^{-3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=729 \left( 1+ \binom{3}{1}(10t) + \binom{4}{2}(10t)^{2} + \binom{5}{3}(10t)^{3} + \ldots \right)"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the coefficient of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"t^{140}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in this expansion is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=729 \times (10)^{140} \times \binom{142}{140}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=2^{140} \times 3^{7} \times 5^{140} \times 71^{1} \times 47^{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b+c+d+e+f+g+h+i+j= \boxed{417}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now the initial problem is to partition 140 in 3 numbers where any perticular number can be 0. Now this is done in 142C2=141"},{"type":"text","text":"71=3","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":"47*71. "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
Let a solution triplet be {a,b,c} ,  then "},{"type":"text","text":"x is in the range    (10a,10a+1−1)(10^{a}, 10^{a+1}-1)(10a,10a+1−1), similarly      y is in the range (10b,10b+1−1)(10^{b}, 10^{b+1}-1)(10b,10b+1−1), 
and z is in the range(10c,10c+1−1)(10^{c}, 10^{c+1}-1)(10c,10c+1−1)","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
    * Also (a+b+c=140) * "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
So the total number of Integral solutions are given by 
        "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"142C2 * (10^{a}*(10-1)*10^{b}*(10-1)*10^{c}*(10-1))"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
       "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"= 47*71*3*10^{140}*9^{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
       "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"=2^{140}*5^{140}*3^{7}*47^{1}*73^{1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"hardBreak"},{"type":"text","text":"
                 The solution follows from this."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{π}{2}\tan(\dfrac{π}{2}x)= \dfrac{1}{(1-x)}-\dfrac{1}{(1+x)}+\dfrac{1}{(3-x)}-\dfrac{1}{(3+x)}+\dfrac{1}{(5-x)}-\dfrac{1}{(5+x)}+\cdots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Differentiating respect to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for two times gives
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{π^3}{8}\sec^2(\frac{π}{2}x)\tan(\frac{π}{2}x)= \dfrac{1}{(1-x)^3}-\dfrac{1}{(1+x)^3}+\dfrac{1}{(3-x)^3}-\dfrac{1}{(3+x)^3}-\cdots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
Take "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x=\dfrac{1}{3}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"
The series becomes
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{π^3}{8}\sec^2(\dfrac{π}{6})\tan(\dfrac{π}{6})= \dfrac{3^3}{2^3}-\dfrac{3^3}{4^3}+\dfrac{3^3}{8^3}-\dfrac{3^3}{10^3}+\cdots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{π^3}{6\sqrt{3}}×\dfrac{8}{27} = 1-\dfrac{1}{2^3}+\dfrac{1}{4^3}-\dfrac{1}{5^3}+\cdots"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1-\dfrac{1}{2^3}+\dfrac{1}{4^3}-\dfrac{1}{5^3}+\dfrac{1}{7^3}-\dfrac{1}{8^3}+\cdots= \dfrac{4π^3}{81\sqrt{3}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#20A900}\boxed{a+b=4+3=7}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For above lemma refer "},{"type":"text","text":"this","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":" solution"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 143 is special ...
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For how many positive integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k<10000"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" does the following statement hold ?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\\times k \\equiv 1 \\pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By using Bezout's theorem we can say that there exists exactly 1 positive integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k<143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which has the stated property . It's possible to find the number by using Bezout's theorem , as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"gcd(67,143)=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus 1 can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143x +67y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for some integers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143 = 2\times 67 + 9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67 = 7 \times 9 +4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"9 = 2\times 4 +1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1 = 9 - 4\times 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = (143 - 2\times 67) - (67- 7\times 9) 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = (143 - 2\times 67) - [2\times 67- 14(143 - 2\times 67) ] "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 - 2\times 67  +14\times 143 -30 \times 67"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 \times 15 - 67\times 30"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore 1 = 143 \times 15 + 67\times (-30)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This tells us that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\times (-30) \equiv 1 \pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" hence "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"67\times (143-30) \equiv 1 \pmod{143}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the smallest positive integer for which given statement hold is 143-30 i.e. "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The other numbers will be of the form "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111 +143k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" as they also will be congruent to 1 mod 143 ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The multiple of 143 next to 10000 is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"143 \times 70 = 10010"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"so the biggest of our required numbers is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"10010-111= 111 + 69 \times 143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence all the numbers we require are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"111,111+143 , 111+2\times 143 ,\dots, 111+ 69\times 143"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus there are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{70}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ............."},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(k<10000)"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            Wow....completely baffled by your solution.......... there's much more for me to learn in modular arithmetic.

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I have another approach..."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since k is the inverse of 67, it is unique in the interval [1, 143]. Since 143 = 11 x 13, 67k is congruent to 1 modulo11 and modulo 13. By property of LCD congruence, this holds true. Using Chinese Remainder Theorem, we found out that k = 111 + 143n so k is congruent to 111 modulo 143. From this, we solve the inequality 111 + 143(n-1) < 10000. And n <= 70 < 70 + (22/143). Hence, the answer is 70."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
